content:
Welcome and Overview

In this module, you will learn about the features, benefits and key capabilities of the Kofax RPA solution.

 

Module Objectives:

  • List and describe the features and benefits of Kofax RPA as it relates to creating and administering robots.
  • Explain how Kofax RPA fits into the Kofax Intelligent Automation Platform.
  • List and locate technical resources, training, and support for Kofax RPA.

Prerequisites:

  • None

 

Lessons:

  • Welcome to Kofax RPA Getting Started Training
    This lesson will introduce you to modules, overview and objectives of the getting started course.
  • What is Kofax RPA?
    This lesson will cover Kofax RPA (robotic process automation) and explain the details about the fastest and most efficient way for you to acquire, enhance and deliver information from virtually any application or data source—including websites, portals, desktop applications and enterprise systems—without any coding. 

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Welcome and Overview

content:
Importing a Project into Design Studio

In this module, we will take a look at how to import a project into Design Studio.

Module Objectives:

  • Define a library and project
  • Import a project to Design Studio

Module Prerequisites:

  • An understanding of Design Studio.
  • Completed Kofax RPA - Getting Started
  • To complete exercises have access to Kofax RPA Design Studio

Lessons:

  • Project - Overview
    In this lesson, you will learn about the Try step and look at how it can be implemented in a Web Automation workflow.
  • Your Turn
    In this lesson, you will practice working with the Try step.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Importing a Project into Design Studio

content:
Architecture and Components

Whatever your involvement with Kofax RPA it is important to understand, some of the basic fundamentals.  In this module, you will learn the Kofax RPA architecture, its key components, and the licensing structure. 

Module Objectives:

  • Describe the Kofax RPA Architecture
  • Identify the Kofax RPA Components
  • Explain the Kofax RPA licensing structure

Prerequisites:

  • None

Lesson:

  • Kofax RPA Architecture and Components
    This lesson will provide an overview of the architecture and components in Kofax RPA. 

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Architecture and Components

content:
Software Installation (Optional)

To help in your understanding of Kofax RPA we encourage you to follow along and do as we do in the demonstrations, to do this you will need access to Kofax RPA software. If you do not have access to the Kofax RPA software yet, then we will show you in this module how to register and download a trial version. You will then be able to follow along with demonstrations in future modules, helping you to understand Kofax RPA software.

Module Objectives:

  • Install the Kofax RPA Trial version on a single computer

Prerequisites:

  • None

 Lesson: 

  • Installing and Licensing Kofax RPA on a Single PC
    This lesson will cover the installation and licensing process when installing the trial version of Kofax RPA. 

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Software Installation (Optional)

content:
Exploring Components and Robots

This module will cover an overview of the primary components of Kofax RPA along with robot basics including how to access existing robot examples.

Module Objectives:

  • Navigate Design Studio.
  • Navigate the Management Console and its components.
  • Explain the structure of Kofax RPA robots.

Prerequisites:

  • None

Lessons:

  • Kofax RPA Design Studio and Management Console
    This lesson will cover the Design Studio and Management Console components of Kofax RPA.
  • Kofax RPA Robots
    This lesson will cover robot basics including how to access existing robot examples in Kofax RPA.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Exploring Components and Robots

content:
Building Your First Robot

In this module, you will be introduced to the various components of a robot and how to build a basic robot to pull information from a website.

 

Module Objectives:

  • Create a project in Design Studio.
  • Configure a Web Automation robot to open a web page.
  • Add Types and Variables to a Web Automation workflow.
  • Configure a Web Automation workflow to extract information from a web page.

Lessons:

  • Creating a Project
    In this lesson, we will take a look at how to create a Kofax RPA Project. A Project is the first building block of creating any robot. 
  • Creating a Robot
    In this lesson, you will learn how to create a Web Automation robot using Kofax RPA Design Studio.
  • Creating Types and Adding Variables
    In this lesson, you will explore and create Types and Variables in Design Studio.
  • Adding Steps to a Robot
    In this lesson, you will configure robot steps to extract specific information from a website.

 

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Building Your First Robot

content:
Web Automation Robot Design

This module introduces you to the basic concepts of Robotic Process Automation, and how you can prepare for the advantages it can bring to you and your organization. We will look at how your organization can plan, prepare and design your workflows.

You can follow lessons in this module in a linear way, progressively building your knowledge and robot building skills as you advance lesson by lesson. You can also use the content in each lesson for reference material, returning at any point to refresh your learning skills.

You will then create a project and start to build a Web Automation workflow to capture information from a web page.                   

Lessons:

  • Planning, Preparation and Design
    In this lesson, we will focus on organizational preparations you need to consider before implementing your robot. We will also take a look at how to choose the correct task to automate.
  • Designing your robot
    In this lesson, you will learn how to record and map your chosen tasks so they can be quickly automated.
  • Creating a Project
    In this lesson, we will take a look at how to create a Kofax RPA Project. A Project is the first building block of creating any robot.
  • Creating a Web Automation Robot
    In this lesson, we will build a Web Automation Robot to load a web page.
  • Creating Types and Adding Variables
    In this lesson, we will add complex types and variables to our workflow.
  • Add Steps to a Web Automation Robot
    In this lesson, we will add steps to search for a product on a webpage, extract information and store it in a variable.

 

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Web Automation Robot Design

content:
Web Automation Workflow - Branches and For Each Loops

Module Overview:

This module introduces you to the linear and non-linear robot execution. We will look at how to add branches to a workflow and review the order of execution.

We will also explore some For Each loops and configure these loops to iterate over items on a webpage.

Module Objectives:

  • Add branches to a workflow.
  • Describe the difference between linear and non-linear robots.
  • Describe three different For Each loop action steps.
  • Configure the For Each Tag Path, For Each Tag and For each URL loop steps.

Module Prerequisites:

  • An understanding of Web Automation workflow.
  • Be able to navigate Design Studio.
  • To complete exercises have access to Kofax RPA

Lessons:

  • Branches
    In this lesson, we will focus on adding branches to a workflow. We will review how robots execute steps in a workflow and discuss a robot's state.
  • For Each loop - Introduction
    In this lesson, we will look at three For Each Loop action steps and review tag finders. We will also look at a scenario we will use for the remaining lessons of this module.
  • For Each loop - For Each Tag Path
    In this lesson, we will look at how we can configure the For Each Tag Path action step to iterate over tags.      
  • For Each loop - For Each Tag 
    In this lesson, we will look at how we can configure the For Each Tag action step to iterate over tags.
  • For Each loop - For Each URL
    In this lesson, we will look at how we can configure the For Each URL action step to iterate over IMG elements on a webpage.
  • Your Turn
    In this lesson, it's your turn to work through For Each loop action step configuration exercises.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Web Automation Workflow - Branches and For Each Loops

content:
The Repeat-Next Loop

In this module, we will take a look at the Repeat-Next loop and how we can implement it into a workflow to iterate over webpages.

 

Module Objectives:

  • Describe the function and features of the Repeat-Next loop.
  • Add the Repeat-Next loop to a Web Automation workflow.

Module Prerequisites:

  • An understanding of Design Studio.
  • Completed Kofax RPA - Getting Started
  • To complete exercises have access to Kofax RPA

 

Lessons:

  • The Repeat Step & Next loop - Overview
    In this lesson, you will learn about the Repeat-Next loop and how it can be implemented in a Web Automation workflow.
  • Your Turn
    In this lesson, you will practice working with the Repeat-Next loop.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: The Repeat-Next Loop

content:
The Try Step

In this module, we will take a look at the Try Step and how we can implement it into a workflow.

 

Module Objectives:

  • Describe the function and features of the Try step.
  • Describe different error handling options.
  • Add the Try step to a Web Automation workflow.

Module Prerequisites:

  • An understanding of Design Studio.
  • Completed Kofax RPA - Getting Started
  • To complete exercises have access to Kofax RPA

Lessons:

  • The Try Step - Overview
    In this lesson, you will learn about the Try step and look at how it can be implemented in a Web Automation workflow.
  • Your Turn
    In this lesson, you will practice working with the Try step.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: The Try Step

content:
Development Database

In this module, we will take a look at the Development Database, including its purpose and how to use it whilst building and developing your workflow. We will also explore some general information about databases and how to map to a production database.

 

Module Objectives:

  • Describe the functionality and purpose of the Development Database.
  • Configure and map to the Development Database in Design Studio
  • Reconfigure a database mapping in Design Studio.
  • List configuration steps in Management Studio to configure a database.

Module Prerequisites:

  • An understanding of Design Studio.
  • Be able to navigate Management Console.
  • To complete exercises have access to Kofax RPA

Lessons:

  • Overview - The Development Database
    In this lesson, you will learn what a Development Database is, including its purpose, its benefits and limitations.
  • Configure the Database
    In this lesson, you will learn how to map to the Development Database and create a table in which to store data.
  • Map to a Microsoft SQL Database
    In this lesson, you will learn how to re-map your workflow to a production database.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Development Database

content:
Working with Excel

Module Overview:

In this module, you will learn how to move data from an Excel file and store it in the Development Database. 

 

Module Objectives:

  • Build a workflow to extract data from an Excel spreadsheet.
  • Configure the Development Database to store information from a variable.
  • Understand looping in Excel

Module Prerequisites:

  • An understanding of Design Studio.
  • Completed Kofax RPA  Learning Path - Web Automation Robot Basic Workflow
  • Have access to Kofax RPA

Lessons:

  • Working with Excel - Overview
    In this lesson, we will focus on how to move data from an Excel Spreadsheet to a Database.
  • Your Turn
    In this lesson, you will build a workflow to extract data from Excel and store it in the Development Database.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Working with Excel

content:
Working with Web Services

Module Overview:

This module is an introduction to using web services in a robot workflow. After introducing some general concepts, several exercises are provided that guide you step by step in using REST-based web services.

Module Objectives:

After completing this module you should be able to

  • Understand which options are provided in Kofax RPA to connect to web services,
  • Understand the differences and commonalities of connecting to SOAP and REST-based web services,
  • Identify some of the Web services provided by RPA itself to run and queue robots,
  • Create robots that call REST web services.

Module Prerequisites:

To call the Google Translate Cloud service in this module's final lesson, you need to have a Google API key.
title: Working with Web Services

content:
Kofax RPA Web Services

Module Overview:

The RPA system also provides web services of its own that can be used for example to run or queue a robot. In this module, you will create robots that will use this functionality to start other robots, a scenario that could be the basis for a divide-and-conquer approach in more complex solutions.

 

Module Objectives:

After completing this module you should be able to

  • Identify some of the Web services provided by RPA itself to run and queue robots
  • Create robots that call another robot using a Call REST Web Service step
  • Create robots queue other robots using the Kofax RPA tasks API

Module Prerequisites:

You will need access to the Management Console with enough privileges to run robots.
title: Kofax RPA Web Services

content:
Using SOAP Web Services

Module Overview:

This module concentrates on using SOAP-based web services,  a slightly older alternative to REST-based services that is still widely used, especially in enterprise applications. We take communication between Kofax RPA and Kofax Communication Manager as an example.

 

Module Objectives:

After completing this module you should be able to

  • Understand which options are provided in Kofax RPA to connect to SOAP-based web services
  • Create robots that call SOAP web services, and in particular to
  • Understand how to communicate with the Kofax Communications Manager to produce documents.

Module Prerequisites:

You need to have access to an instance of Kofax Communications Manager but if you don't, you can skip the practical parts of the exercises. You are encouraged to read through the material and watch the demonstration videos to get a feel for the work involved.
title: Using SOAP Web Services

content:
AI Web Services with the Cloud AI step

Module Overview:

This module introduces the Cloud AI step that is available in version 11.2. The Cloud AI step provides a low code alternative to using AI web services provided by major vendors.

Module Objectives:

After completing this module you should be able to

  • Create robots in version 11.2 of RPA that use the new Cloud AI step
  • Use the Cloud AI step to translate text using the Google Cloud Translate API
  • Use the Cloud AI step to identify objects in images using the Google Cloud Vision API

Module Prerequisites:

To call the Google Translate Cloud service you need to have a Google API key.
title: AI Web Services with the Cloud AI step

content:
Email Triggers

Module Overview:

You can set up your robots to start upon receiving emails from a certain email account. You can extract attachments, header information, and email content, or use emails, simply as a trigger to start robots. In this module, you will learn how to trigger robots by email.

Module Objectives:

  • Describe email triggers
  • Setup email triggers
  • Build a robot that processes email

Module Prerequisites:

  • None
title: Email Triggers

content:
Kapplets

This module introduces the general concepts related to the Kapplets application and provides step-by-step exercises for several common tasks that involve the administration of Kapplets and a section on the installation of the Kapplets application on a Tomcat server.

The target audience is administrators who want to manage access to Kapplets. Note that the general concepts might be of interest to robot developers as well, but no separate module is provided on building robots that are used in Kapplets for the simple reason that any robot can be used in a Kapplet as well.
title: Kapplets

content:
The Password Store

Module Overview:

This module introduces the general concepts related to the Password Store and provides step-by-step exercises for several common tasks that involve the administration of password entries and retrieving passwords inside a robot workflow. The target audience is administrators who want to manage the Password Store and robot developers who want to use passwords from the password store in a robot workflow.

Module Objectives:

After completing this module you should be able to

  • Describe the Password Store
  • Perform common tasks regarding the Password Store

Module Prerequisites:

None
title: The Password Store

content:
Introduction

In Kofax RPA you can create Desktop Automation robots that can automate work processes involving Windows and Java applications on your networked computers. Because desktop Automation is different from web automation, Design Studio has a dedicated workflow language and steps for this purpose. In this module, we will explore the differences in functionality between the Desktop Automation workflow and the Web Automation workflow. We will introduce you to the procedure for editing a Desktop Automation workflow and build a simple Desktop Automation robot. 

  • Introduction to Desktop Automation Workflow
    In this lesson, you will learn what Desktop Automation is and how it can be used for a robot.
  • Overview of editing a Desktop Automation workflow
    In this lesson, you will review the capabilities of the Desktop Automation workflow editor and review some relevant components
  • Build a Simple Desktop Automation Workflow 
    In this lesson, you will create a simple Desktop Automated workflow which is controlled by a Web Automated robot.

Prerequisites

This module assumes that you are familiar with Web Automated robot concepts and you have completed the Kofax RPA Getting Started Learning path.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Introduction

content:
Opening and Closing a Web Page

In Kofax RPA you can create Desktop Automation robots that can automate work processes that involve interaction with applications, including Windows and Java applications on your networked computers. Because desktop Automation is different from web automation, Design Studio has a dedicated workflow language and steps for this purpose. In this module, we will build a workflow which will open a webpage, extract information and close the web page. 

Module Learning Objectives:

  • Create a Desktop Automation Workflow
  • Call Desktop Automation robots from a Web Automation robot
  • Work with the Chromium browser
  • Understand Guarded steps

Lesson overviews:

  • Overview
    In this lesson, we will explain what a Desktop Automation workflow is and introduce you to the scenario we will build a workflow for.
  • Opening and closing a web page
    In this lesson, you will learn how to call and configure Desktop Automation robots to open and close a web page.
  • Retrieving category link information 
    In this lesson, you will learn how to configure Desktop Automation robots to retrieve links to individual product categories and work with variables.

Prerequisites

This module assumes that you are familiar with Web Automation workflow concepts and that you have completed the Kofax RPA Getting Started Learning path.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Opening and Closing a Web Page

content:
Extracting information

In Kofax RPA you can create Desktop Automation robots that can automate work processes that involve interaction with applications, including Windows and Java applications on your networked computers. Because desktop Automation is different from web automation, Design Studio has a dedicated workflow language and steps for this purpose. In this module, we will build a workflow which will loop over webpages and retrieve information from individual product webpages on the Hardy Hardware web site. 

Module Learning Objectives:

  • Configure the For Each Text part Action step to extract information from a comma-separated list.
  • Configure a For Each loop step to extract href information to a comma-separated list.
  • Extract information from a webpage

  • Module Overview
    In this lesson, you will learn about the scenario for our workflow and take a high-level look at the solution we will build.
  • Configure Product Category URLs 
    In this lesson, you will learn how to configure action steps to create product category URLs.
  • Retrieve product link information
    In this lesson, you will learn how to reuse existing Desktop Automation robots in your workflow and loop over pages to extract product link information.
  • Configure Product Category URLs 
    In this lesson, you will learn how to configure action steps to create product URLs.
  • Extracting information 
    In this lesson, you will configure Desktop Automation robot to extract information from a webpage and return the information to variables in your workflow.

Prerequisites:

This module assumes that you are familiar with Web Automated robot concepts and you have completed:

  • The Kofax RPA Getting Started Learning path.
  • The first module in this series DA Workflow - Opening and Closing a webpage.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Extracting information

content:
Guarded Choice Steps and Guards

The Guarded Choice step is used to set up a number of conditions, each associated with some actions. Whichever condition or guard is satisfied first, its associated actions or steps are executed. One of the means to avoid robot execution issues utilized in RPA Desktop Automation logic is Guarded Choice steps and Guards. This module will focus on the different types of guarded choice steps available. We will then explore how to make a robot error-proof by using guarded choice steps and Guards.

  • Desktop Automation - Guarded Choice Step Introduction
    Here you will learn the purpose and different types of Guarded Choice and how to manually add a guarded step to a robot.
  • Desktop Automation - Guarded Choice Step Demonstration
    Here you will learn how to improve a Desktop Automation robot by utilizing a loop step, a scroll step and guarded choice step.

Prerequisites

This module assumes that you are familiar with the Desktop Automation Robot concepts introduced in the "Desktop Automation Concepts module".

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Guarded Choice Steps and Guards

content:
Visit Multiple Web Pages

In Kofax RPA you can create Desktop Automation robots that can automate work processes that involve interaction with applications, including Windows and Java applications on your networked computers. Because desktop Automation is different from web automation, Design Studio has a dedicated workflow language and steps for this purpose. In this module, we will build a workflow which will loop over webpages and retrieve information from individual product webpages on the Hardy Hardware web site. In this module, we will configure our workflow to retrieve all items from the Categories and Products web pages.

Module Learning Objectives:

  • Copy Desktop Automation workflows
  • Add a Scroll step to your workflow
  • Modify step configuration to access the All button on a web page.

Lessons:

  • Overview
    In this lesson, you will learn about the scenario for our workflow and take a high-level look at the solution we will build.
  • Visit Multiple Web Pages  
    In this lesson, you will copy a Desktop Automation robot to and configure it to visit all items on a web page.

Prerequisites:

This module assumes that you are familiar with Web Automated robot concepts and you have completed:

  •  The Kofax RPA Getting Started Learning path.
  • Completion of the first module in this series -  DA Workflow - Opening and Closing a webpage.
  • Completion of the second module in this series -  DA Workflow - Extracting Information.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Visit Multiple Web Pages

content:
Desktop Automation Service

In Kofax RPA, you can create Desktop Automation robots that can automate work processes on Windows and java applications on your networked computers. To automate applications on a remote computer, you need to install the Desktop Automation Service on that PC and connect the service to the Management Console.

In this module, we will look at installing the Desktop Automation Service on remote computers and how devices are mapped to the management console. 

  • Desktop Automation Service
    In this lesson, we will look at the Desktop Automation service and the installation procedure.
  • Desktop Automation Service - Configuration
    In this lesson, we will review the steps required to configure the Desktop Automation service to use the Management Console connection or a Single User connection.
  • Build a basic Desktop Automation robot
    In this lesson, we will build a basic robot which interacts with a remote device.

Prerequisites

This module assumes that you are familiar with the Desktop Automation Robot concepts introduced in the "Introduction to Desktop Automation" module.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Desktop Automation Service

content:
Working with a Custom Project

Here you will learn how to configure a workflow using a custom project configured and trained to classify and extract information from a submitted electronic document. 

Module Objectives:

  • Add validation steps to a Document Transformation workflow.
  • Configure Callback to send a validated document to an RPA workflow.
  • Extract invoice information from electronic invoice documents.

Module Prerequisites:

  • An understanding of Design Studio.
  • An understanding of web automation robots
  • Completed the DTS | Document Transformation Service module
  • Complete the DTS | Working with a Predefined Project

Lessons:

  • Working with a Custom Project
    In this lesson, we will take a look at Document Transformation workflow we will build to processes electronic invoices.
  • Preparing the Workflow
    In this lesson, we will build the base structure for the invoice workflow. 
  • Document Transformation
    In this lesson, we will configure our Desktop Automation robot to send input documents to the Document Transformation server. 
  • Validation and Extraction
    In this lesson, we will configure our Desktop Automation robot to check if the transformed document is valid or not.
  • Dealing with Callback
    In this lesson, we will configure callback so a REST robot URL is sent to the validation server. 
  • Your Turn
    In this lesson, you will practice working with a Document Transformation workflow.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Working with a Custom Project

content:
Robot File System Concepts

Module overview

This module provides an introduction to the Robot File System (RFS). It introduces general concepts and gives an overview of the architecture. 

The target audience is anyone who wants to know more about the Robot File System and how it can be used in robots. This includes administrators, architects, solution engineers as well as robot developers of any skill level.

Learning objectives

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the main concepts of the Robot File System and illustrate its benefits
  • Identify the main components that are part of the Robot File System and how they interact together
  • Understand the different roles and associated privileges that control access to the Robot File System
  • Understand how the Management Console grants access to a running robot
  • Provide some examples of how the Robot File System can be used in robots and highlight some limitations
title: Robot File System Concepts

content:
Configuring the Robot File System

Overview

This module provides step-by-step instructions on installing the Robot File System application in a Tomcat server.

It starts with a short introduction highlighting the steps needed to install the Robot File System application and then proceeds with a practical exercise consisting of a video demonstration, details in the text, and an instruction guide that will allow you to follow the step-by-step instructions in your own tempo.

Learning objectives

By the end of this module, you will be:

  • Familiar with the main concepts relevant to installing the Robot File System application on a Tomcat server
  • Able to install and configure the application yourself
title: Configuring the Robot File System

content:
Using the Robot File System

Overview

This module provides an introduction to using the Robot File System (RFS). It shows how to create a robot that can read and write files to a Robot File System.

The target audience is anyone who wants to know more about the Robot File System and how it can be used in robots. This includes administrators, architects, solution engineers but is primarily targeted at robot developers of any skill level.

The module consists of a short introduction followed by a practical lesson that provides a demonstration video, more detailed information in text, and a step-by-step instruction manual so that you can follow along in your own tempo.

Learning objectives

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  • Understand the main concepts relevant to robots that make use of the Robot File System
  • Create a robot that reads and writes files on a Robot File System
title: Using the Robot File System

content:
Document Transformation Service

Module Overview:

Here you will learn how to call the Document Transformation Server from a Desktop Automation step.

 

Module Objectives:

  • Describe Document Transformation
  • Verify the Document Transformation service
  • List configuration options available in the Document Transformation step

Module Prerequisites:

  • An understanding of Design Studio.
  • Completed Kofax RPA  Learning Path - Desktop Automation Robot Basic Workflow
  • Have access to Kofax RPA

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Document Transformation Service

content:
Working with a Predefined Project

Here you will learn how to configure a workflow using the Sentiment predefined project to return a sentiment value for a submitted document.

Module Objectives:

  • Build a workflow using the Sentiment predefined project
  • Extract a sentiment value from a document
  • Return a Sentiment value to a Web Automation workflow

Module Prerequisites:

  • An understanding of Design Studio.
  • Completed the DTS | Document Transformation Service module

Lessons:

  • Working with the Sentiment Project
    In this lesson, you will learn about the Document Transformation and look at how it can be implemented in a workflow.
  • Your Turn
    In this lesson, you will practice working with a Document Transformation workflow.

Product Version(s): 11.0
title: Working with a Predefined Project

content:
Document Transformation and Validation

Module Overview:

In this module, we build a robot that extracts information from scanned documents and integrates it with a validation server.
We explore a document transformation scenario that involves building a robot that can extract data from a scanned survey form and is able to forward documents to a validation server if the classification or extraction confidence is too low and let a person confirm or correct the results.

Module Prerequisites:

This module involves configuration and workflow steps that go beyond a straightforward Document Transformation step.

If you need a refresher on the basics of using a Document Transformation step with a custom transformation project, you are highly encouraged to have a look a the following learning cloud module:

DTS | Document Transformation Service

 

Module Objectives:

After completing this module you should be able to

  • identify the components of a Document Transformation solution that may involve validation
  • understand the steps in an RPA workflow that perform document transformation and validation
  • build a robot that implements a workflow that involves document transformation and validation
title: Document Transformation and Validation

content:
Attended Automation

Module Overview:

Attended automation is a way to automate remote computers by creating a robot that reacts to an event on that remote device, such as the opening or closing of an application. In this module, we will explore attended automation and build a basic attended automation robot.

 

Module Objectives:

  • Define attended automation
  • Build a basic attended automation workflow
  • Upload an attended automation robot to the management console

Module  Prerequisites

It is recommended you complete the following learning path:

  • Robot Developer | Desktop Automation Robot Basic Workflow
title: Attended Automation

content:
RPA 11 | Using Custom Actions

Module Overview:

This module introduces Customs Actions and the practical lessons focus on developing a robot that uses a Custom Action and on making sure the robot can run on a RoboServer. It is aimed at anybody who wants to use Custom Actions or simply wants to learn the concepts.

Module Objectives:

After completing this module you should be able to

  • understand what Custom Actions are and what their relation is to connector packages
  • import connector packages in an RPA project
  • use custom actions
  • make sure a robot with a Custom Action can be run on a RoboServer.

Module Prerequisites:

The practical lessons focus on using Custom Actions that are defined in a connector package. This package is provided for download in the resources section. You do not need any programming skills to use a connector package. You can always use Custom Actions while developing robots in the Design Studio, but to run a robot with a Custom Action on a RoboServer, you may need to have access to the RoboServer itself to enable this feature. Details are provided in the last lesson.
title: RPA 11 | Using Custom Actions

content:
RPA 11 | Developing Custom Actions

Module Overview:

A Custom Action can then be used by any robot developer in the same way other steps can be used, regardless of their skill level. In this module, we have two practical lessons that walk you step by step through creating new Custom Actions.

Module Objectives:

After completing this module you should be able to

  • extend an existing connector package with an action written in Node.js
  • create a new connector package with actions written in Python
  • understand and change the manifest of a connector package
  • identify the specific prerequisites for Python-based custom actions

Module Prerequisites:

In the lessons, new Custom Actions are developed in Node.js and Python, but code examples are provided that you can use directly, even if you do not have experience in using these languages.\nSome programming skills are of course required but if your experience is with another programming language you'll probably have no problems following these lessons.
title: RPA 11 | Developing Custom Actions

content:
RPA | Best practices

Module Overview:

Building robots in Kofax RPA is fairly easy to learn, but as soon as a robot is needed that solves a more complex problem, it may become harder to design one that meets requirements, functions reliably, is easy to understand and maintain, and offers quick returns in the time invested in its development.

This module addresses these areas by offering guidance in the form of best practices and tips.

Module Objectives:

After completing this module you should know the most common best practices in the following areas:

  • Documentation
  • Solution Design
  • Patterns and anti-patterns in robots
  • Desktop Automation specific design
  • Debugging and testing

Module Prerequisites:

There are no specific prerequisites for this module, and although most examples and videos use version 11.2, best practices apply equally to all versions. In those instances where we use a feature that is only available in a newer version, this will be clearly indicated.
title: RPA | Best practices

content:
RPA | Running Robots using the API

Module Overview:

In this module, we introduce the Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) provided with Kofax RPA and show some working examples of .Net applications written in C#.

The programs that we present are meant as a starting point for programmers who wish to run robots directly from their application.

We show examples that use the .Net API as well as an example that uses the Kofax RPA REST API, and although this module is not a programming tutorial, we do illustrate the available features in the APIs by discussing the example code.

Module Objectives:

After completing this module you should be able to:

  • Run a robot from a C# application and retrieve any results
  • Queue a robot from a C# application and process any results asynchronously
  • Create a C# application that uses the tasks REST API to queue robots and poll for results
  • Understand the differences between the functionality available in the different APIs

Prerequisites:

  • RPA version 11.2.0.5  or newer.
  • Basic programming knowledge
title: RPA | Running Robots using the API
